content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Write a function `ispersonal` that returns a trait if the provided Vehicle type is a personal vehicle for everyday driving. All vehicles are subtypes of AbstractVehicle. Function must work for types: Car, Motorcycle, Bus, Truck. The first two should return true, the latter two should return false . The function should default to false for any other subtype of AbstractVehicle. Provide an example.

Here is how you can solve this problem using Julia:

```julia
abstract type AbstractVehicle end

struct Car <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Motorcycle <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Bus <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Truck <: AbstractVehicle; end

ispersonal(::Car) = true
ispersonal(::Motorcycle) = true
ispersonal(::Bus) = false
ispersonal(::Truck) = false

function ispersonal(vehicle::AbstractVehicle)
    return false
end
```
In this code, we first define an abstract type `AbstractVehicle`. Then we define concrete types of vehicles: `Car`, `Motorcycle`, `Bus`, and `Truck`. Each of these types is a subtype of `AbstractVehicle`. 

We then provide two functions `ispersonal` that return true if the vehicle type provided is one of the two personal vehicle types: Car or Motorcycle. We also define another function `ispersonal` for any other kind of `AbstractVehicle`, which defaults to false. If you call `ispersonal(::Car)` or `ispersonal(::Motorcycle())`, it will return true, while calling `ispersonal(::Bus)` and `ispersonal(::Truck)` would return false.

Here is an example:
```julia
julia> Car() |> ispersonal
true

julia> Motorcycle() |> ispersonal
true

julia> Bus() |> ispersonal
false

julia> Truck() |> ispersonal
false
```
